strategic_profile.executive_summary: Ohio University, established in 1804, is a comprehensive public research university in Athens, Ohio. It is recognized for its beautiful campus, strong sense of community, and diverse academic offerings across arts, sciences, business, and health professions. The university emphasizes experiential learning and student success.
strategic_profile.market_position: Regional public university with strong programs in journalism, business, and healthcare, known for vibrant campus life and historical significance.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Seeks well-rounded students demonstrating academic readiness, intellectual curiosity, and a desire to contribute positively to a residential campus environment. A holistic review considers academic record, extracurricular involvement, and personal essays.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Ohio University benefits from a strong brand identity within Ohio and surrounding states.
The university's picturesque campus and strong residential life are key differentiators.
Opportunities exist to further leverage alumni networks for career services and fundraising.
Maintaining competitive program offerings, particularly in high-demand fields, is crucial for market share.
Addressing affordability and student debt remains a strategic imperative for continued accessibility.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Known for a lively and engaging residential experience, a strong sense of community, numerous student organizations, and a significant presence of Greek life. Campus events, athletic support, and a picturesque setting foster strong student connections.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Athens is a classic college town, highly walkable and bike-friendly. Most essential services and campus facilities are within easy reach. University transit system and limited public city transit support off-campus living, but personal vehicles are often secondary for daily use.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Active research enterprise across various disciplines, with notable strengths in biomedical sciences, environmental studies, and engineering. Facilitates interdisciplinary collaborations and provides extensive undergraduate research opportunities, contributing to regional innovation and knowledge creation.

current_status.test_policy_details: Ohio University has a test-optional pathway for freshman applicants to its Athens campus, meaning standardized test scores (ACT or SAT) are not required for admission. Applicants can choose to submit scores if they wish to have them considered. If multiple scores are submitted, Ohio University will use the highest composite ACT or the highest combined math and critical reading SAT scores, as the university superscores. Applying test-optional will not negatively impact consideration for admission, merit-based scholarships, or honors and scholars programs. Undergraduate Admissions considers class rank, strength of curriculum, optional ACT and/or SAT scores, and GPA. Self-reporting of scores is permitted initially.
current_status.international_notes: The international acceptance rate is for the application year 2023. Data for 2021 and 2022 is unavailable. The university is generally more competitive for international applicants due to additional requirements like English proficiency, contrasting with an overall acceptance rate of around 85-87%.
current_status.state_rates_notes: Ohio University is a public institution. The university's overall acceptance rate is approximately 85%. However, Ohio University reports its admission statistics without distinguishing between in-state and out-of-state applicants, making separate acceptance rates for residents and non-residents unavailable.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Record first-year student enrollment of 4,550 for the Athens campus. The incoming class had a record high incoming average GPA of 3.67, with more than a quarter in the top ten percent of their high school graduating classes. Includes 142 students ranked No. 1 in their high school graduating classes and over 300 winners of the Governor's Merit Scholarship.

Ohio University welcomed 4,345 new students for fall 2024, following record-setting incoming classes in the previous two years. The university saw more than 27,000 applications for Fall 2024. Growth was noted in out-of-state students, with 628 non-Ohio students enrolling. The entering class had an average high school GPA of 3.64, with over 12% ranked in the top 5% of their high school graduating class.
The undergraduate acceptance rate was 84.8%. The number of applicants grew by 2.68% between 2022 and 2023. Ohio University-Main Campus had an overall enrollment yield of 21.1%.

Ohio University welcomed its largest first-year class in the institution's history, with 4,441 incoming first-year students to the Athens Campus, a 21% increase from 2021. The class had a record-high incoming average high school GPA and a record number of Ohio residents (3,908).
The acceptance rate for Fall 2021 was 88.56%.

gpa.notes: Ohio University considers a holistic review process. The middle 50 percent of the Fall 2024 freshman class were in the top 12-42% of their graduating high school classes. Other factors considered for admission include the rigor of high school curriculum, test scores (if submitted), essays, letters of recommendation, and extracurricular activities.

testing.policy_note: Test-optional. Ohio University superscores SAT by considering the highest section scores across all test dates and uses the highest composite ACT score from all test dates.

demographics.first_gen_legacy_notes: A full quarter of the Athens freshman class are first-generation students (Fall 2025).

men.note: Data likely pertains to the 2023 admission cycle, reported as of March 2, 2025.

women.note: Data likely pertains to the 2023 admission cycle, reported as of March 2, 2025.

colleges.name: College of Arts and Sciences
colleges.housing_profile: General university housing options available. South Green dorms (e.g., Pickering, Brown, Mackinnon, Crawford, Adams, Carr, Sowle, Luchs, Tanaka) are conveniently located for students across all majors. The 'Front Four' are traditional with communal bathrooms, while the 'Side Five' (Adams, Carr, Sowle, Luchs, Tanaka) are more renovated, suite-style with shared bathrooms, student kitchens, on-site laundry, and central A/C (except Adams).
colleges.student_archetype: Diverse students interested in liberal arts, natural sciences, social sciences, humanities, pre-professional tracks, and secondary education. They seek a broad academic foundation and opportunities to explore various fields.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students seeking a comprehensive education across a wide range of disciplines, those pursuing pre-professional studies, or aspiring secondary educators. Strong fit for individuals who value intellectual breadth and diverse academic inquiry.

colleges.name: College of Business
colleges.housing_profile: General university housing options. The 'Side Five' dorms on South Green (Adams, Carr, Sowle, Luchs, Tanaka) are noted as renovated, suite-style, and well-located for students of all majors, including those in business.
colleges.student_archetype: Career-oriented students focused on practical business applications, management, marketing, sales, and analytics. They are motivated to gain professional skills and engage in a variety of business fields.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for students pursuing degrees in business administration, marketing, finance, accounting, or other business-related fields. Good for those who are driven by career development and seek a curriculum with strong management education.

colleges.name: College of Fine Arts
colleges.housing_profile: **Lincoln Hall (East Green)**: A dedicated Fine Arts Residential Learning Community (RLC) featuring dance and art studios, a music and computer lounge, and flexible multipurpose spaces. Rooms offer individual seasonal temperature controls and a sink. It is conveniently located across from other Fine Arts academic buildings.
colleges.student_archetype: Creative, collaborative individuals with interests in dance, music, theater, and visual arts. They are eager to produce artistic work with community impact and thrive in an immersive and inclusive arts environment.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Highly recommended for students with strong artistic talents who desire a collaborative, immersive arts living and learning experience. Ideal for those interested in the Fine Arts RLC in Lincoln Hall, benefiting from integrated studio and rehearsal spaces.

Dr. Aethelred Eldridge (Painter, former faculty)

colleges.name: College of Health Sciences and Professions
colleges.housing_profile: General university housing options. South Green dorms are mentioned as being conveniently located for students across all majors.
colleges.student_archetype: Students driven to improve health outcomes and provide care, with interests in health-related fields like exercise physiology and human services. They are motivated to positively impact community and individual well-being.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Best suited for students pursuing careers in health care, exercise physiology, nutrition, social work, or other health and human services professions. Ideal for those committed to public health and patient-centered care.

colleges.name: Honors Tutorial College
colleges.housing_profile: **Honors and Scholars Housing** in **Jefferson Hall and Read Hall** on East Green, featuring study and community spaces. HTC students receive first preference for these scholars' dorms. **Gamertsfelder and Washington Halls** on East Green are also designated honors dorms, generally renovated, with a traditional price point, and restricted to honors students. Jefferson Hall offers renovated rooms, a ground-floor grocery market, cafes, a deli, study rooms, a mailroom, and laundry facilities on each floor.
colleges.student_archetype: Exceptional, driven, and intellectually curious students who thrive on personalized, rigorous academic study, including one-on-one tutorials. They are often high-achieving leaders, broadly involved on campus, and committed to making original contributions to their field through a thesis.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Highly recommended for self-directed, motivated students seeking a personalized, Oxford/Cambridge-style tutorial education with close faculty mentorship. Ideal candidates typically have strong academic records (e.g., 30 on ACT, 1300 on SAT, top 10% class placement) and a desire for curriculum flexibility and independent research.

majors.name: Advanced Computing
majors.special_requirements: Superior academic ability, potential for self-motivated study and research, additional essays, interview.

core_courses: Customized tutorial program with a faculty member (8 tutorials, typically 3-15 hours each)
Core Mathematics, Science, Computer Science, and Electrical Engineering courses as determined by tutorial plan.
electives: Internships and/or study abroad with special permission.

notable_professors: Dr. Wojciech Jadwisienczak (Professor; Graduate Chair, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science)
Dr. Savas Kaya (Professor, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science)
Dr. J. Jim Zhu (Professor, Electrical Engineering and Computer Science)
majors.notes: This program offers a flexible curriculum and one-on-one tutorials. Admission is highly competitive and primarily for freshmen. Internal transfers are limited. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog.

majors.name: Journalism
majors.special_requirements: Superior academic ability, potential for self-motivated study and research, additional essays, interview, two academic letters of reference, writing sample.

core_courses: Customized tutorial program in Journalism (8 tutorials, typically 3-15 hours each)
Regular journalism courses as required by the E.W. Scripps School of Journalism

notable_professors: Dr. Victoria LaPoe (Director of Studies/Contact person)

Dr. Aimee Edmondson (Professor, E.W. Scripps School of Journalism)
majors.notes: The HTC Journalism program offers exceptional students one-on-one relationships with faculty and culminates in an honors thesis. Admission is highly competitive and primarily for freshmen. Internal transfers are limited. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog. [cite: 4, 7, 11, 12, 20, 22, 24]

majors.name: English
majors.special_requirements: Superior academic ability, potential for self-motivated study and research, additional essays, interview, two academic letters of reference, writing sample.

core_courses: Customized tutorial program in English (8 tutorials, typically 3-15 hours each)

Dr. Mark Halliday (Poetry)
Dr. Linda Zionkowski (Samuel and Susan Crowl Professor of Literature)

Internal transfers are limited. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog. [cite: 4, 7, 11, 12, 20, 24]

colleges.name: The Gladys W. and David H. Patton College of Education
colleges.housing_profile: General university housing options. Patton Hall is the academic building for the college, with classrooms and labs. Jefferson Hall on East Green is located near the College of Education complex.
colleges.student_archetype: 'Leaders-in-the-making' in education, recreation, and human and consumer science fields. They are dedicated to serving and representing the college, often demonstrating outstanding academic achievement and exemplary student leadership, and are involved in student organizations and advisory councils.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Suited for students pursuing careers in education, counseling, sports pedagogy, recreation, or consumer sciences. A good fit for those committed to leadership, community engagement, and experiential learning in human service professions.

colleges.name: Russ College of Engineering and Technology
colleges.housing_profile: General university housing options. No specific dorms are exclusively designated for this college. All rooms are air-conditioned and furnished with an XL-twin bed, desk, chair, dresser, and closet space.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious problem-solvers with a strong background and interest in STEM fields. They are driven by innovation and technical challenges.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Strong STEM background is highly recommended. Ideal for students dedicated to engineering and technology disciplines who seek rigorous academic challenges and practical problem-solving opportunities.

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: One year of chemistry or physics
One additional year of chemistry, physics, or an engineering science (e.g., engineering principles, robotics, computer science, or digital electronics)

colleges.name: Scripps College of Communication
colleges.housing_profile: General university housing options. No specific dorms are exclusively designated for this college.
colleges.student_archetype: Leaders on campus, engaged in shaping and delivering messages and news. They are hands-on, interested in emerging technologies, interdisciplinary collaboration, and storytelling. Students are described as 'bold, curious problem-solvers who are passionate about making positive change'.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Recommended for individuals passionate about communication (journalism, visual communication, media arts, public relations), eager for experiential learning, and aspiring to leadership roles in media and communication industries. Ideal for those who want to innovate and contribute ethically and creatively to a rapidly evolving field.

majors.name: Journalism News and Information
majors.special_requirements: Application for transfer, resume, two letters of recommendation, 500-word essay, work samples.

core_courses: JOUR 1010 The Future of Media OR JOUR 1050 Introduction to Mass Communication (3)
JOUR 2311 Introduction to Multiplatform Reporting and Writing (3)

notable_professors: Dr. Hans Meyer (Associate Director for Undergraduate Studies, E.W. Scripps School of Journalism)
Dr. Aimee Edmondson (Professor)
Dr. Elizabeth Meyers Hendrickson (Professor)
majors.notes: Admission to the E.W. Scripps School of Journalism is competitive for both freshman and transfer students. Transfer applications are accepted twice per academic year. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog.

majors.name: Strategic Communication
majors.special_requirements: Application for transfer, resume, two letters of recommendation, 500-word essay, work samples.

JOUR 2500 Introduction to Advertising and Public Relations (3)
JOUR 4900 Senior Capstone in Strategic Communication (3)

notable_professors: Dr. Dan Farkas (Professor of Strategic Communication)
Dr. Parul Jain (Professor of Strategic Communication)
Dr. Victoria LaPoe (Director of Studies/Contact person for Honors Journalism)
majors.notes: Admission to the E.W. Scripps School of Journalism is competitive for both freshman and transfer students. Transfer applications are accepted twice per academic year. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog.

majors.special_requirements: Internal transfers are on a space-available basis only and application does not guarantee acceptance.

MDIA 2200 Introduction to Media Arts and Studies (3)
MDIA 4900 Capstone in Media Arts and Studies (3)

notable_professors: Dr. Josh Antonuccio (Director, School of Media Arts & Studies)
Dr. Eddie Ashworth (Associate Professor)
Dr. Tyler Ayres (Associate Professor + Transfer & Advising Coordinator)
majors.notes: Transfer students to Media Arts & Studies should have a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog.

majors.name: Visual Communication (Photojournalism, Informational Graphics & Publication Design, Interactive Media, Commercial Photography)
majors.special_requirements: Portfolio review required for admission to a B.F.A. Visual Communication major.

core_courses: VICO 1000 Introduction to Studies in Visual Communication (3)
VICO 2514 Introduction to Basic Publication Design (3)
VICO 2561 Introduction to Basic Web Design (3)
VICO 4900 Senior Capstone in Visual Communication (3)

notable_professors: Dr. Terry Douds (Professor of Instruction)
Dr. Stan Alost (Professor of Instruction)
Dr. Robert Stewart (Professor Emeritus)
majors.notes: Applicants are initially admitted to University College as Undecided-Intending Visual Communication major and must submit a separate application and portfolio for consideration to the School of Visual Communication. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog.

majors.name: Communication Studies

core_courses: COMS 1020 Introduction to Undergraduate Communication Studies (1)

notable_professors: Dr. Judith Yaross Lee (Charles E. Zumkehr Professor and the Director of Honors Tutorials in the School of Communication Studies)
Dr. Candice Rios Wenmoth (Associate School Director for Undergraduate Studies)
Dr. Christine Suniti Bhat (Professor, Counseling and Higher Education)
majors.notes: The program emphasizes theoretical understanding and practical application of communication. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog.

colleges.name: University College
colleges.housing_profile: Collaborates with Housing and Residence Life for Residential Learning Communities (RLCs). Supports the **First Gen Experiential Living Opportunity (ELO)**, a residential community for first-generation students. Also offers the **Transfer Student Community** in Adams Hall (South Green) or Bromley Hall (West Green).
colleges.student_archetype: Students who are exploring academic interests before declaring a major, first-generation students, and transfer students. They seek support during their transition to college, guidance in academic pathfinding, and opportunities to build strong peer networks.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: An excellent choice for undeclared students, first-generation students seeking comprehensive support, or transfer students looking for a smooth transition and community integration. Provides a structured environment for academic exploration, personal development, and network building.

majors.name: Applied Management

core_courses: BA 1500 Introduction to Business Communication and Professional Skills (3)

notable_professors: Dr. Ana Rosado Feger (Contact person, Business Studies Major)
Dr. Sara Hartman (Contact person, General Science Emphasis Major)
majors.notes: The Applied Management program is fully online and designed for students seeking advancement in business, often with previous associate degrees. Data source: Ohio University 2025-2026 Undergraduate Catalog. [cite: 4, 7, 11, 12, 16, 18, 19, 21, 23, 25, 27, 30, 32, 33, 34, 35, 37, 41, 42, 47]

colleges.name: Voinovich School of Leadership and Public Service

minors_certificates: Environmental Studies Sustainability and Resilience Undergraduate Certificate

application_deadlines.notes: For Fall 2026 incoming freshmen; offers priority consideration for direct entry to academic programs, merit scholarship programs, and University honors and scholars experiences.

Extended deadline for the OHIO Admission Promise (for automatic general University admission with a minimum 3.0 GPA) and priority FAFSA consideration date. Applications are considered on a rolling basis after the Early Action deadline.

supplemental_requirements.details: One optional essay is available for all applicants. This space can be used to describe any academic challenges, preparation for academic and career objectives, or any additional information to be associated with the application. It can also be used to explain discrepancies in academic history. The recommended length is 250-500 words.

One optional essay is encouraged. The prompt asks how academic, extracurricular, community service, or work experience has shaped and prepared the applicant to succeed in OHIO's College of Business, focusing on leadership potential and engagement. The recommended length is 600 words.
One optional essay is encouraged. The prompt asks applicants to explain why they have chosen their particular program of study. The recommended length is 600 words.

Applicants are required to submit two essay responses. Prompt 1: "This essay is optional. You may use this space to describe any academic challenges you have faced, your preparation for success in your academic and career objectives, or any additional information that you would like to have associated with your application." This is the same as the general optional essay. Prompt 2: "Please explain why you have chosen your particular program of study." Additionally, how have your experiences prepared you for a tutorial education?

supplemental_requirements.target_program: School of Music (Undergraduate Admission & Talent-Based Scholarships)
supplemental_requirements.deadline: Specific on-campus audition dates for January 24, 2026, February 7, 2026, February 14, 2026, and February 16, 2026. Remote or video auditions can be arranged if an in-person audition is not possible.
supplemental_requirements.details: Students must audition for consideration to the program, and this audition also serves for talent-based scholarships. Applicants should be prepared to perform specific audition requirements and may be asked to demonstrate sight-reading or simple aural skills.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Music Ensembles (Fall 2025 - Symphonic Band, Wind Symphony, Symphony Orchestra)
supplemental_requirements.deadline: During the first week of classes in August 2025, with some auditions occurring the weekend before classes begins.
supplemental_requirements.details: Placement auditions are required. Winds and percussion students should prepare specific excerpts. String music majors auditioning for Symphony Orchestra should prepare excerpts, while non-majors can perform a short selection of their choice and/or scales. No audition is required for University Band.

supplemental_requirements.deadline: Audition details for the 2025/2026 Performance Team will be available in Spring 2025.
